channel.title: Julia Tufts
channel.description: Julia Tufts personal site, mathematics, programming, piano, music, games, python, C#, Unity3d

item.title: Trees
item.description:
More fractals, this time playing around with trees.

The mouse position on the sketch determines the span and the branching factor. The horizontal axis maps to the span (the distance from the leftmost branch to the rightmost): left to right –> 0 to 180 degrees. The vertical axis maps to the branching factor (how many branches at each step): up to down –> 2 to 7. The minimum branch length to keep generating branches is a function of the branching factor so that the tree doesn’t explode in your computer :]

[Challenge: Make and post a Processing sketch every day for 100 days]

item.title: Koch Snowflake
item.description:
Another favorite fractal - the Koch snowflake.

The sketch runs through five iterations but I wish it were infinitely many.

[Challenge: Make and post a Processing sketch every day for 100 days]

item.title: Cantor Set
item.description:
Cantor Set (two of them actually!) - take a line and keep removing the middle third.

Recursion is great.

[Challenge: Make and post a Processing sketch every day for 100 days]

item.title: Lightning
item.description:
Sorry I’m late on this one. Here’s some lightning:

Boom.

[Challenge: Make and post a Processing sketch every day for 100 days]

item.title: Game of Life
item.description:
More from the chapter of cellular automata, here is Conway’s Game of Life.

Click on the sketch and press space to reset!

[Challenge: Make and post a Processing sketch every day for 100 days]

item.title: Cellular Automata
item.description:
Skipping ahead four chapters in The Nature Of Code because I’m starting to feel restless. Here is two dimensional cellular automata.

I find it so incredible that a small finite set of rules can result in intricate pattern (like Sierpinski above) or complete chaos (like below).

Incidentally I am feeling better today.

[Challenge: Make and post a Processing sketch every day for 100 days]

item.title: Heart Signal
item.description:
Scaling things.

I am sick today, send love.

[Challenge: Make and post a Processing sketch every day for 100 days]

item.title: Eyeballs
item.description:
I’ve sort of been wanting to write something that looks like a vector field, an array of short lines pointing in the direction of an oncoming force.

But then I decided that it would be more amusing to makes eyes that stare at your mouse cursor.

[Challenge: Make and post a Processing sketch every day for 100 days]

item.title: Square Rotation
item.description:
Playing around with rotations, nested pushMatrix() / popMatrix() blocks.

The overlapping squares come in two flavors: red/green/blue and yellow/cyan/magenta.

[Challenge: Make and post a Processing sketch every day for 100 days]

item.title: Indecision
item.description:
I don’t really know what I’d like to do in life. I’ve just scaled the cliff face of university to discover an overgrown jungle at the top. I have no idea what the best way to approach it is, so I try hacking my way through one path, have second thoughts and double back, then try hacking my way through another and another. Never really getting anywhere, and never figuring out what the right way to do it was.

I do know that I would like to program. But what exactly? How do I figure that out? Should I go back to university? Should I try to find a job? I keep thinking around in circles, chopping at bits of that jungle once in a while but never making any real progess.

I’ve come to the conclusion that I’m not going to figure any of that out until I try a lot of things, write a lot of code, and undoubtedly make a lot of mistakes. The worst thing to do is get stuck and not do anything at all. I’m leaving for Hacker School in New York City in 12 days. I’m both excited and terrified to be thrown into the code cauldron, work on projects and meet new people with similar interests. I just need to find the self-direction to pick a thing and work hard at it, and not get held back by indecision.
